#Text=Choose a Food Thermometer
#Text=An accurate food thermometer is an essential tool in any kitchen .
#Text=A good thermometer can enable you to cook meat and poultry safely , roast vegetables to perfection , and create various baked masterpieces .
#Text=In order to select the right one for your kitchen , you will need to evaluate different types of food thermometers and consider how much you are willing to spend .
#Text=Furthermore , if you ’ll be using this thermometer to cook meat , there are a few other options to consider .
#Text=By weighing all of these factors , you are sure to select the best thermometer for you .
#Text=Steps
#Text=Evaluating Different Types of Thermometers
#Text=Choose a digital thermometer .
#Text=Non-digital " dial " thermometers — sometimes called bi-metallic stem thermometers — are no longer your best option .
#Text=Over time , the metal on these instruments expands and contracts , causing the inner workings to shift and show an incorrect temperature .
#Text=Instead , digital thermometers are easily the best choice .
#Text=They are easy to read , remarkably accurate , and available in a wide variety of styles .
#Text=There are many types of digital thermometers , ranging in price from as little as $ 5 to well over $ 100 .
#Text=Instant read thermometers , infrared thermometers , and thermocouple readers are all available in digital models .
#Text=Try an “ instant read pocket thermometer . ”
#Text=A common , effective , and relatively inexpensive option is an “ instant read pocket thermometer . ”
#Text=These digital thermometers give an instant temperature reading by inserting a metal probe into the food .
#Text=A good option is the Classic Super-Fast Thermapen for $ 79 ( from ThermoWorks or Amazon ) .
#Text=A less expensive , but still great , option is the Super-Fast Pocket Thermometer ( RT600C ) for $ 19 ( from ThermoWorks or Amazon ) .
#Text=Experiment with “ thermocouple readers ” and probes .
#Text=If you ’d like something a little more high-end , you may prefer to use a thermocouple reader and probes .
#Text=Thermocouple readers offer flexibility and accuracy by recording temperatures at multiple locations on the food , by way of thermocouple probes .
#Text=A good choice for a reader is the Therma Differential Thermocouple Meter for $ 129 ( from ThermoWorks ) .
#Text=The probes are sold separately .
#Text=A good choice for these is the Stainless Steel K-Type Thermocouple Insertion Probe ( set of 2 ) for $ 11.99 ( on Amazon ) .
#Text=Consider an infrared thermometer .
#Text=An infrared thermometer can provide an accurate temperature reading without ever touching the food .
#Text=Simply point the infrared gun at various points on your food to get temperature readings .
#Text=This is a great option is you ’d like to keep the look of your food intact .
#Text=A good option is the Food Safety Infrared ( IRFS ) for $ 69 ( from ThermoWorks or Amazon ) .
#Text=Choosing a Meat Thermometer
#Text=Try a “ leave-in digital meat thermometer . ”
#Text=Leave-in thermometers are an excellent choice for slow cooking meat and poultry ( as when roasting a turkey ) .
#Text=Simply insert a metal probe into your meat and leave it there while cooking .
#Text=A digital display outside the oven conveys the temperature , by way of a thin cord or via Bluetooth .
#Text=A good choice for this is the Chef 's Digital Leave-In Meat Thermometer for $ 39.99 ( from Oxo ) .
#Text=Choose an “ instant-read digital meat thermometer . ”
#Text=When it comes to instant read meat thermometers , there are two basic designs .
#Text=One is wand with a bulb at the end .
#Text=The other is a hinged , folding probe .
#Text=The second design is a bit more expensive , but offers a more sophisticated probe with faster results .
#Text=A great choice for a hinged instant-read digital thermometer is the Lavatools Thermowand for $ 28 ( on Amazon ) .
#Text=Look for additional features .
#Text=Different types of meat thermometers will offer additional features .
#Text=Generally , the more features a thermometer has , the more expensive it will be .
#Text=So consider whether or not any of these following features will be useful to you :
#Text=Audible alarm/alert ( that tells you when meat is ready ) .
#Text=Auto shut-off ( to conserve battery when not in use ) .
#Text=Pre-set meat temperature ( according to USDA guidelines ) .
#Text=Programmable timer ( that you can set manually ) .
#Text=Back-light ( this enables you to see the display in dark rooms or outdoors at night ) .
#Text=Determine
#Text=How Much You Want to Spend
#Text=Assess how often you ’ll use it .
#Text=Food thermometers can range widely in price , from as low as $ 5 to as much as $ 150 .
#Text=The number one factor in how much you spend should be how often you cook .
#Text=If you will be using the thermometer often , it is worth it to spend a little more .
#Text=Determine what it will be used for .
#Text=If you will be cooking a great deal of poultry or meat , a good quality thermometer is essential for food safety .
#Text=If you will be cooking only vegetable dishes and baked goods , you can probably get away with a less expensive model .
#Text=Decide on a budget .
#Text=After considering how often you ’ll use it and what it will be used for , you must finally consider how much money you have available to spend .
#Text=All three of these factors taken together , will help you come up with a budget .
#Text=Armed with this figure , you can best select the thermometer that suits your needs .
